awd_abstract_narration:
CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Electromyography (EMG)-based Assistive Human-Machine Interface Design: Cognitive Workload and Motor Skill Learning Assessment

Over 100,000 people in the United States have upper limb amputations. Such amputations are usually associated with substantial disabilities. Activities of daily living may no longer be possible or require additional effort and time. To restore functional ability as fully as possible, amputee patients use upper-limb prostheses controlled by Electromyography (EMG)-based human-machine interfaces (HMIs). However, over 50% of prosthetic users report device dissatisfaction and abandonment due to frustration in use. In order to increase accessibility and utility of EMG-based assistive HMIs, it is critical to investigate the cognitive workload associated with using these systems for supporting motor skill rehabilitation and activities of daily living. In addition, with differences in individual muscle make-up and control, it is necessary to customize EMG-based assistive HMIs to particular patient conditions. However, at this time, there exists little to no general guidance on what interface control features may be more or less conducive to supporting learning and performance of psychomotor tasks. By testing various control interface prototypes in a validated motor skill learning simulation as well as high-demand, real-time tasks, specifically simulated driving, the investigators seek to provide design guidance for engineers to develop EMG-based assistive HMI technologies for various applications. This project also provides education and training for young industrial, computer science, and biomedical engineering students in assistive technology design and development.

The technical aims of the project are divided into three thrusts including (1) identifying cognitive load costs of EMG-based HMIs using computational cognitive performance models and machine learning algorithms - The developed cognitive workload models will be used for predicting learning potential and performance outcomes of variations of control interface designs, (2) demonstrating fundamental motor skill training through integration of the EMG-based HMI with virtual reality (VR) simulations - In particular, the investigators are interested in assessing whether the difference in cognitive load of using EMG-based HMIs translates to variations in learning potential and retention of psychomotor task skills, (3) translating fundamental motion components trained in the VR psychomotor test to a real-world application by demonstrating the possibility of operational driving control with an EMG-based HMI in a high-fidelity driving simulator - This thrust provides empirical validation for the findings regarding differences in cognitive load of using EMG-based HMIs, as well as the potential for increased learning and operational task performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Electromyography (EMG)-based human-machine interfaces (HMIs) are powerful tools for applications such as powered prosthetic limbs. However, despite the many advancements made in research, the acceptance rate of these devices among amputees remains low. When designing HMIs, many previous studies have focused on performance measures such as task completion duration as the main predictor of the success of the HMI for clinical application. Nevertheless, other psychomotor performance of users, such as their learning rate in using HMIs and cognitive workload, are equally, if not more, important to determine the utility of the HMIs and user acceptance of the technology. Hence, in this project, the investigators in biomedical, electrical, and industrial engineering from Texas A&M University (TAMU), the University of Florida (UF), and NC State University (NC State) collaborated and aimed to provide design guidance for engineers to develop EMG-based assistive HMI technologies for various applications. 

The biomedical and electrical engineers in our research group at NC State are responsible to (1) advance and deliver EMG-based HMI design for prosthesis control and VR operation, (2) investigate how HMI design and offline HMI prediction accuracy influences psychomotor performance metrics, and (3) collaborate with the project team to implement HMI-based VR control on TAMU and UF sites and assist with research results interpretation and dissemination.  

Our research team at NC State advanced the capabilities of EMG-based HMIs for the control of upper limb prostheses in practice. Among the major innovations of this project was the novel design of an EMG-based HMI. This transformative HMI framework combines the capabilities of neuromusculoskeletal modeling with robust, user-specific machine learning-based personalization in a strategy that is notably different from existing approaches in literature. This HMI design is aimed towards further expanding the accessibility of advanced controllers for multi-joint prosthetic hands to individuals with varying degrees of limb loss. Furthermore, the team investigated the online psychomotor performance of HMI users (such as learning rate for HMI use, task performance metrics, the user’s physical efforts, and cognitive load) while performing virtual tasks using multiple EMG-based HMIs. This work strongly linked psychomotor performance with the accuracy of estimations made by the HMI calculated during offline data analysis. These results, which highlight metrics that have large impacts on the overall success of the HMI in practice, will serve as an important guideline for future HMI development. Finally, the team at NC State University collected data from able-bodied subjects using different EMG-based HMIs for prosthesis control to complete functional tasks.  We used eye-tracking glasses and questionnaire responses to quantify the cognitive workload. In collaboration with the research teams at TAMU and UF, the data was used to build a model to estimate the cognitive workload in users. Overall, the research conducted in this project has introduced new concepts and development guidelines to drive future advancements EMG-based HMIs. This work will contribute to the future clinical application of more reliable and dexterous EMG-based prostheses, which will bring significant improvements in the quality of life for amputees.

The work completed in this project was disseminated in multiple peer-review journals and conferences with the intention of guiding and improving the efficiency of research in EMG-based HMIs. During this research, our team was able to train four Ph.D. students. One student was awarded an NIH Ruth L. Kirschstein Predoctoral Individual National Research Service Award. Another two Ph.D. students to complete their programs and graduate: one employed as a research scientist at Meta and the other continuing with M.D. training. Finally, four outreach events related to this project were held for over 200 K-12 students, including those from underrepresented groups, in which the team was able to encourage interest in STEM concepts.
